docs.lead_paragraph: Canadian researchers say that when they surveyed women about their body images, they found that women who lived in wealthier areas were more likely to be dissatisfied. The article is in the current Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health.

headline.main: Image Is in the Eye of the Bank Account

docs.abstract: University of Montreal researchers, in survey published in current issue of Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, finds that women who live in wealthier areas are more likely to be dissatisfied with their body image, although their own income did not appear to play role; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Canadian researchers say that when they surveyed women about their body images, they found that women who lived in wealthier areas were more likely to be dissatisfied.    The article is in the current Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health.

docs.lead_paragraph: A common practice in treating premature babies is to keep them in darkened rooms -- the better, the thinking goes, to simulate the womb. But researchers from Duke University say in a report in the current issue of Pediatrics they have evidence that exposing some infants to light seems to help them grow faster.

headline.main: Light May Help Premature Babies Grow

docs.abstract: Duke University researchers, in report in current issue of Pediatrics, find evidence that exposing premature babies to light seems to help them grow faster (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Silent Child,'' by Prof. Laurent Danon-Boileau, Oxford University Press, $25. There was Rachid, a ''slightly peculiar child'' who, at the age of nearly 4, did not use language to communicate. He could, however, read numbers, and when left alone he would move his fingers about in endless intricate patterns, sometimes chanting to himself in strings of incomprehensible words.

headline.main: Helping Children Break Out of Their Silence

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book The Silent Child by Prof Laurent Danon-Boileau, about children who cannot speak; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1990 Wendy Schlessel Harpham was a 36-year-old family physician and mother of three young children -- Rebecca, 6, Jessica, 4, and William, almost 2 -- when she learned that the swollen lymph nodes in her groin were malignant, an indolent form of a cancer called non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, or NHL, for which there was no known cure. NHL, which affects the lymphatic tissues, is one of only a few major cancers that have been rising in incidence and mortality since the early 1970's. The annual number of new cases of NHL has nearly doubled since then. This year an estimated 53,900 men and women will be found to have a forms of this disease, and 24,400 people will die of it. It is the fifth leading cause of cancer deaths, with a mortality rate that is rising faster than all other cancers except melanoma of the skin.
docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, whose incidence and mortality rate have been rising since early 1970's; focuses on case of Dr Wendy Schlessel Harpham, family physician and mother of three, who, after repeated courses of treatment, has managed to survive and has been in remission for nearly three years; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers are reporting a correlation between regions of the country where gun ownership is high and the number of children who die from gunshot wounds. Researchers from the Harvard School of Public Health reported in February in The Journal of Trauma that states with more guns had many more gun deaths among children -- homicides, suicides and accidents.

headline.main: Mapping Out Gun Hazards for Children

docs.lead_paragraph: In the Sacramento City Unified School District in California, Inger Lindholm is affectionately known as the Lice Queen. A nurse for more than 40 years, she is highly skilled at detecting lice creeping through a child's scalp and even better at the difficult task of spotting the eggs, or nits, that the bugs leave behind on the hair shafts.

headline.main: Seeking New Ways to Fight a Persistent Foe: Lice

docs.abstract: Article on new ways being sought to combat head lice; several studies show head lice have grown resistant to permethrin, active ingredient in anti-lice shampoos most often recommended by physicians; Archives of Dermatology has published study by University of Miami researcher Terri Meinking on most and least effective prescription and over-the-counter formulas; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study by researchers at Dartmouth reports that teenagers whose parents place no restrictions on their viewing R-rated movies appear much more likely to use tobacco or alcohol. The findings appear in the current issue of Effective Clinical Practice. The lead author, Dr. Madeline A. Dalton, and her colleagues based their report on a survey of 4,544 students in the fifth through eighth grades in New Hampshire.

headline.main: When 'R' Stands for Risky for Teenagers

docs.abstract: Study by Dartmouth College researchers, published in current issue of Effective Clinical Practice, finds that teenagers whose parents place no restrictions on their viewing R-rated movies appear more likely to use tobacco or alcohol; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For centuries, doctors have dreamed of curing families. We are all too aware of illnesses that pass from one generation to the next. Some illnesses are infectious like syphilis. Others like diabetes can be partly genetic. Still others like alcoholism may be a combination of genes and behavior. Regardless of origin, family illnesses can create havoc through the years.

headline.main: One by One, A Family Is Treated

docs.abstract: Psychiatrist David Hellerstein Cases column describes curing woman, husband and other family members of anxiety and panic disorders (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Guy Book: An Owner's Manual for Teens,'' by Mavis Jukes, Crown, $12.95. Modeled after a car owner's manual, this engaging and candid book, with 16 chapters, takes preteenage and teenage boys on an informative, and sometimes witty, road trip through growing up that covers most of the maintenance, safety and operating instructions they'll need.

headline.main: A Candid Guidebook for Growing Up Male

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews The Guy Book: An Owner's Manual for Teens by Mavis Jukes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The practice of delivering babies has long been influenced by traditions, based on the theories of popular obstetricians rather than on scientific proof. Recently, though, some routine practices have been put through the rigors of scientific testing and have been found ineffective at best and harmful at worst.

headline.main: In Many Delivery Rooms, a Routine Becomes Less Routine

docs.abstract: Article on drastic reduction in episiotomies done in hospital delivery rooms over past 20 years, which have declined to 39 percent in 1998 from 64 percent among women having vaginal deliveries; recent studies show that women who have episiotomy have greater risks of complications, including serious lacerations involving rectum and anal sphincter, than those who do not; photo; graph (M)
